title: How to Identify a Potcake Dog

steps.title: Check the dog's size.
steps.content: Check the dog's size. Without a strict breed standard, Potcakes can greatly vary in size from less than 25 pounds (11 kg) to as much as 100 pounds (45 kg) or more, though they are typically described as medium-sized dogs. A general size seen in Potcakes is between 35–55 pounds (16–25 kg), with a height of about 22–24 inches (56–61 cm) when fully grown. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Look at the ears.
steps.content: Look at the ears. Potcakes are usually seen with either cropped or folded ears. [3] X Research source Some ears are cropped in a "helicopter" style.

steps.title: Examine the eyes.
steps.content: Examine the eyes. The eyes of a Potcake are described as expressive and intelligent. [4] X Research source A Potcake's eyes aren't one specific color, but they wear much of their emotion in their eyes.

steps.title: View the muzzle.
steps.content: View the muzzle. A common trait seen in Potcakes is a long muzzle. The muzzle may resemble that of a terrier or hound. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Understand that Potcakes vary in structure.
steps.content: Understand that Potcakes vary in structure. Potcakes all generally appear similar, but there are differences among them. Their features vary to some extent, and dogs from different islands may have different overall appearances. There is no set appearance that every Potcake has.

steps.title: Look at their coat's texture and appearance.
steps.content: Look at their coat's texture and appearance. Potcakes generally have short, smooth coats with little to no undercoat. However, a Potcake with a shaggy or long coat may be seen, though this is rarer.

steps.title: Recognize the coat color.
steps.content: Recognize the coat color. The coat of a Potcake may be one of many colors. Brown is perhaps the most commonly seen coat color, and other colors include red, yellow, cream, black, and white. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Identify coat patterns.
steps.content: Identify coat patterns. Potcakes may be seen with a wide variety of coats. Though many are a solid color, some are combinations of multiple colors (such as black and tan), parti, or other patterns.

steps.title: Take notice of survival instincts.
steps.content: Take notice of survival instincts. Many Potcakes are street dogs, so anticipate strong survival instincts from one. Even domesticated Potcakes have come to inherit these instincts. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Watch for intelligence.
steps.content: Watch for intelligence. Not only do Potcakes have "street smarts", but they're all-around intelligent dogs. They respond well to training and are fairly easy to train compared to other breeds. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Recognize adaptability.
steps.content: Recognize adaptability. Potcakes are highly adaptable dogs. Despite being street dogs, they're quick to adapt if they're taken to a new home and only take a short amount of time to adjust to the new environment. [10] X Research source

steps.title: See if the dog is affectionate.
steps.content: See if the dog is affectionate. Most Potcakes are very loving and affectionate. Once someone gains their trust, Potcakes show extreme loyalty and care toward them. Some Potcakes may occasionally show signs of timidity or aggression, though this is not entirely common.

steps.title: Look for a desire to be around people.
steps.content: Look for a desire to be around people. Despite being street dogs, Potcakes enjoy having the company of humans. They seem to bond almost immediately with people. [11] X Research source
